entry.title: Dr. Kaylyn Clark joins the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute!

link.title: Dr. Kaylyn Clark joins the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute!

entry.content:
We are happy to announce our recruitment of Dr. Kaylyn Clark as a Postdoctoral Fellow in the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ.

Kaylyn recently completed her Ph.D. in Genomics and Computational Biology from the University of Pennsylvania, during which she studied the genetic basis of Alzheimer‚Äôs Disease (AD) using statistical and genetic modeling in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) utilizing polygenic risk scores (PRS). To further study the polygenic architecture of AD, Kaylyn co-developed a joint genetic score called MetaGRS.

We are excited to have Kaylyn joining our team as we further study the germline and somatic basis of pediatric high-grade gliomas which form in patients with the tumor syndrome, Neurofibromatosis. Welcome, Kaylyn! üëè
entry.summary: We are happy to announce our recruitment of Dr. Kaylyn Clark as a Postdoctoral Fellow in the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ.

entry.title: Dr. Bicna Song joins the Brain Tumor Institute Bioinformatics Core!

link.title: Dr. Bicna Song joins the Brain Tumor Institute Bioinformatics Core!

entry.content:
We are happy to announce our recruitment of Dr. Bicna Song as a Bioinformatics Scientist in the Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) Bioinformatics Core at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ.

Bicna joins us after a very successful postdoctoral fellowship with Dr. Wei Li at CNH, where she developed expertise in transcriptomic data analysis, including bulk RNA-Seq, single-cell RNA-Seq, and Perturb-Seq. Her innovative work led to the creation of the Perturbation-Response Score (PS), a novel method to quantify how individual cells respond to genetic perturbations at single-cell resolution, providing powerful insights into cellular heterogeneity and gene function.

We are excited for Bicna to bring her expertise to the BTI Bioinformatics Core, where she will contribute to advancing precision medicine for pediatric brain tumors. Her deep knowledge in computational transcriptional biology and data-driven discovery will be invaluable to our mission. Welcome, Bicna! üëè
entry.summary: We are happy to announce our recruitment of Dr. Bicna Song as a Bioinformatics Scientist in the Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) Bioinformatics Core at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ.

entry.title: New press release - Q&A with Dr. Rokita: Building Bioinformatics Infrastructure at the Brain Tumor Institute

link.title: New press release - Q&A with Dr. Rokita: Building Bioinformatics Infrastructure at the Brain Tumor Institute

entry.content: Dr. Rokita recently sat down with the press team at Children‚Äôs National to discuss her laboratory‚Äôs research, the development of the Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) Bioinformatics Core, and her collaborative and open science vision for the future. Read all about it here!

entry.title: New tumor predisposition syndrome described!
entry.content: We are happy to announce the publication of ‚ÄúGermline pathogenic DROSHA variants are linked to pineoblastoma and Wilms tumor predisposition‚Äù, an international collaboration in which we describe a new tumor syndrome characterized by pathogenic germline DROSHA variants. Read more about it here.
entry.summary: We are happy to announce the publication of ‚ÄúGermline pathogenic DROSHA variants are linked to pineoblastoma and Wilms tumor predisposition‚Äù, an international collaboration in which we describe a new tumor syndrome characterized by pathogenic germline DROSHA variants. Read more about it here.

entry.title: Alex Sickler joins the Rokita Lab!

link.title: Alex Sickler joins the Rokita Lab!

entry.content:
We are thrilled to welcome Alex Sickler as a Bioinformatics Engineer in the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) Bioinformatics Core at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ. Alex joins us after many productive years of bioinformatics engineering and infrastructure management work at GeneDx, the National Cancer Institute, and the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP).

While at CHOP, Alex played a critical role in scaling modules from the Open Pediatric Cancer (OpenPedCan) Project and has contributed to the development of the Kids First single-cell and single-nuclei RNA-Seq workflows. Additionally, he led implementation of automated data ingest workflows and applications for the Kids First Data Resource Center.

We‚Äôre excited to have Alex join us at CNH as we build our BTI Bioinformatics Core, contributing to our mission of advancing precision medicine for pediatric brain tumors. Welcome, Alex! üëè
entry.summary: We are thrilled to welcome Alex Sickler as a Bioinformatics Engineer in the Rokita Lab and Brain Tumor Institute (BTI) Bioinformatics Core at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ. Alex joins us after many productive years of bioinformatics engineering and infrastructure management work at GeneDx, the National Cancer Institute, and the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP).

entry.content: We were thrilled to be a part of the recent publication, ‚ÄúImaging Clusters of Pediatric Low-Grade Glioma are Associated with Distinct Molecular Characteristics‚Äù, led by our collaborator Dr. Anahita Fathi Kazerooni. Read more about it here.

link.title: Germline manuscript is online at medRxiv!

entry.content: Our latest manuscript, ‚ÄúGermline pathogenic variation impacts somatic alterations and patient outcomes in pediatric CNS tumors‚Äù, work led by Dr. Ryan Corbett, is now preprinted on MedRxiv!

entry.title: Kinome reprogramming in neuroblastoma manuscript published!

link.title: Kinome reprogramming in neuroblastoma manuscript published!

entry.content: From Dr. Yael Mosse‚Äôs laboratory, we are happy to see the work of Dr. Smita Matkar, ‚ÄúKinome reprogramming of G2/M kinases and repression of MYCN contribute to superior efficacy of lorlatinib in ALK-driven neuroblastoma‚Äù, published today. We were happy to have played a small role in this work! Read more about it here.

We were happy to have played a small role in this work! Read more about it here.

entry.title: Preprint describing NRCAM, a new pediatric high-grade glioma neoepitope online!

link.title: Preprint describing NRCAM, a new pediatric high-grade glioma neoepitope online!

entry.content: As a part of our splice-derived neoepitope identification research, we partnered with Dr. Andrei Thomas-Tikhonenko‚Äôs laboratory at Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia in which they validated an NRCAM splice event as a targetable immunotherapeutic target for pediatric high-grade gliomas. Please read more in ‚ÄúNeuronal cell adhesion molecule (NRCAM) variant defined by microexon skipping is an essential, antigenically distinct, and targetable proteoform in high-grade glioma‚Äù here.
entry.summary: As a part of our splice-derived neoepitope identification research, we partnered with Dr. Andrei Thomas-Tikhonenko‚Äôs laboratory at Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia in which they validated an NRCAM splice event as a targetable immunotherapeutic target for pediatric high-grade gliomas. Please read more in ‚ÄúNeuronal cell adhesion molecule (NRCAM) variant defined by microexon skipping is an essential, antigenically distinct, and targetable proteoform in high-grade glioma‚Äù here.

entry.title: Dr. Ryan Corbett joins the Rokita Lab!

link.title: Dr. Ryan Corbett joins the Rokita Lab!

entry.content:
We are thrilled to welcome Dr. Ryan Corbett as a Senior Bioinformatics Scientist in the Rokita Lab at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ. Ryan joins us after two years of outstanding work under the mentorship of Dr. Rokita at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP).

Ryan has played a pivotal role in advancing bioinformatics tools and applications critical for pediatric cancer research, including co-development and maintenance of the germline pathogenicity tool, AutoGVP, essential involvement in the Open Pediatric Cancer (OpenPedCan) Project, and development contributions for two key CAVATICA applications, Pathogenicity Preprocessing and AlleleCouNT. Ryan‚Äôs research productivity speaks for itself. He is lead author of a recently accepted manuscript in NeuroOncology, entitled, ‚ÄúGenetic ancestry superpopulations show distinct prevalence and outcomes across pediatric central nervous system tumors from the PBTA and PNOC‚Äù and lead author of an upcoming preprint, ‚ÄúIntegrated germline and somatic profiling of pediatric CNS tumors reveals incidental findings and novel tumor biology‚Äù. Ryan has collaborated on six additional manuscripts in the pediatric brain tumor field over the past two years, demonstrating his dedication to team-based science. In addition to his research, Ryan is passionate about mentoring and teaching. He has started leading workshops for computational staff at both CHOP and CNH, exemplifying his dedication to fostering a collaborative learning environment.

We‚Äôre excited to have Ryan continue his impactful work here at CNH, contributing to our mission of advancing precision medicine for pediatric brain tumors. Welcome, Ryan! üëè
entry.summary: We are thrilled to welcome Dr. Ryan Corbett as a Senior Bioinformatics Scientist in the Rokita Lab at Children‚Äôs National Hospital (CNH) üéâ. Ryan joins us after two years of outstanding work under the mentorship of Dr. Rokita at the Children‚Äôs Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP).
